pullRequest.body:
We define proper action of a group on a topological space, and we prove that in this case the quotient space is T2. We prove that if a Hausdorff group acts properly on $X$, then $X$ is Hausdorff. We also give equivalent definitions of proper action using ultrafilters and show the transfer of proper action to a closed subgroup.
We show that if $X \times X$ is Hausdorff and compactly generated then the action is properly discontinuous if and only if it is continuous in the second variable and proper in the sense defined here. The "compactly generated" assumption is to be rephrased with typeclass inference in the future.

Co-authored-by: @EtienneC30
Co-authored-by: @florestan 
Co-authored-by: @ADedecker 

---

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

(I'm assigning you, Anatole, since you definitely know the relevant mathematics, but if you think you have participated in this PR to much to review it, feel free to assign eg Floris instead)

The PR description says "Again compactly generated spaces are not yet in Mathlib". I think they now are, aren't there? CC @dagurtomas

> The PR description says "Again compactly generated spaces are not yet in Mathlib". I think they now are, aren't there? CC @dagurtomas

Indeed I see they are. The property I need from compactly generated spaces is the direct implication in the following:
```
example {X : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X] [T2Space X] :
    CompactlyGeneratedSpace X ↔
      (∀ s, IsClosed s ↔ ∀ (K : Set X), IsCompact K → IsClosed (s ∩ K))
```
I managed to prove it. Now the interesting result in this PR is for locally compact spaces or T1 spaces, which are currently not deduced from compactly generated space by typeclass inference. The converse implication above would allow to prove the results without typeclass inference, but

1. it's probably better if everything is automatically inferred
2. I'm not even sure the converse direction is true. I have a proof in mind but I have trouble with universes, which I've never manipulated. Here's my attempt: #15066.

> > The PR description says "Again compactly generated spaces are not yet in Mathlib". I think they now are, aren't there? CC @dagurtomas
> 
> Indeed I see they are. The property I need from compactly generated spaces is the direct implication in the following:
> 
> ```
> example {X : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X] [T2Space X] :
>     CompactlyGeneratedSpace X ↔
>       (∀ s, IsClosed s ↔ ∀ (K : Set X), IsCompact K → IsClosed (s ∩ K))
> ```
> 
> I managed to prove it. Now the interesting result in this PR is for locally compact spaces or T1 spaces, which are currently not deduced from compactly generated space by typeclass inference. The converse implication above would allow to prove the results without typeclass inference, but
> 
> 1. it's probably better if everything is automatically inferred
> 2. I'm not even sure the converse direction is true. I have a proof in mind but I have trouble with universes, which I've never manipulated. Here's my attempt: [Lemma about compactly generated spaces #15066](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15066).

You probably want `X : Type u` and `CompactlyGeneratedSpace.{u, u} X` for your characterisation. The implications T1 => compactly generated and locally compact => compactly generated would be welcome contributions. For the former, I think the universe parameter can be completely general, for the latter maybe you need `.{u, u}` again.
Note also that the current API on compactly generated spaces is very minimal, and should be expanded to prove theorems like the ones you mention.
Thanks, I've nailed it! I'll see what I can do for the instances.

Here's a first wave of comments. These are mostly about style and shortening some proofs. If you have questions about any of them, please ask, the goal is also that you learn some tricks. Also, if you feel that any suggestion is making the code significantly less readable, feel free to object!
This PR seems to be in good shape, but I will need a topologist to sign off.

Looks good to me but I need a topologist to sign off

maintainer merge

This is really nice! Thanks for this work from LftCM at CIRM.

Please also update the PR description to reflect the change about compactly generated spaces. Other than that and my few comments below, I'm happy!

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ProperSMul G X ↔ ContinuousSMul G X ∧ (∀ ℱ : Ultrafilter (G × X), ∀ x₁ x₂ : X, ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion T2Space (Quotient (MulAction.orbitRel G X)) := by ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion T2Space (Quotient (MulAction.orbitRel G X)) := by ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion simp? ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion simp? ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion simp? ```

```suggestion
    [FirstCountableTopology X]
```
This is a bit hidden in the sea of purely stylistic error messages, but note that Lean complains here that you actually didn't use separation of the domain in your proof. In fact, as I explained on Zulip, we can change the proof to get rid of first countability as well.

Also, note that you can change the `FirstCountableTopology Y` to `SequentialSpace Y`, which is a bit weaker (although admittedly this is not spectacular). This is again a good example of "stupid things you can learn by formalizing your proof": I noticed that the key lemma `IsSeqClosed.isClosed` only required `SequentialSpace`, so I tried changing the hypothesis, and sure enough Lean is still happy!

In general, we tend to write all hypotheses before the colon, to avoid having to introduce them. This would mean something like:
```suggestion
    (f : X → Y) (hcont: Continuous f)
    (h : ∀ (K : Set Y), (IsCompact K → IsCompact (f ⁻¹' K))) : IsProperMap f := by
```

Also, note that the linter doesn't want to have line breaks just before `:= by`.

```suggestion
  refine ⟨by assumption, ?_, ?_ ⟩
```

These parentheses are unnecessary. Also, `assumption` is great while writing code, but in general we prefer to replace it with the actual assumption. You can do that easily by adding a `?` after the `by` and clicking on the suggestion.

Here the linter complains about a "non-terminal simp". I don't remember how much we talked about it during the week, but here's what it means:

Since the behaviour of `simp` is determined by the set of lemmas which are tagged `simp`, it can change very often, sometimes due to seemingly unrelated changes. Most of the time these changes make `simp` more powerful, which means that if `simp` used to close the goal, it will probably still be able to do so after the change. This means that using `simp` is perfectly fine *as long as it closes the current goal*. If that is not the case, then `simp` may be able to do more progress by becoming more powerful, which could break the rest of the proof.

The typical fix for this is to use `simp?` and use the suggested `simp only`. But in this case all it does is unfold composition, which you can avoid entirely by doing
```suggestion
      ext n
      rw [<-(hs n).2]
      rfl
```
or even
```suggestion
      ext n
      exact (hs n).2.symm
```
Same problem as above, except this time you can just get rid of the `simp` altogether: it's just doing some unfolding, which will be overwritten by the `change` just below.

Here you can make your life easier simply by writing down what you want to prove in the `have`: the `simp` is doing nothing, and `change` following a `have :=` can almost always be rewritten by stating what you want to prove in the `have` (which is also more readable!). Here, that could be
```suggestion
    have fs'_tendsto : Tendsto ((f ∘ s') ∘ φ) atTop (𝓝 (f a)) := 
      tendsTo_comp_continuous htendsto hcont
    rw [<- seq_factor] at fs'_tendsto
```
and you could even include the rewriting inside of it:
```suggestion
    have fs'_tendsto : Tendsto (seq ∘ φ) atTop (𝓝 (f a)) := by
      rw [seq_factor]
      exact tendsTo_comp_continuous htendsto hcont
```

Just wanted to point out here that, even with keeping your skeleton of proof instead of the one I suggested on Zulip, we could get rid of the first countability assumption on X relatively easily, by taking an ultrafilter on $\mathbb{N}$ finer than `atTop` instead of a subsequence.

There is nothing wrong with using sequential closedness here, but note that the theorem "the limits of a sequence with values in a closed set stay in that closed set" has actually nothing to do with sequences (see [IsClosed.mem_of_tendsto](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Basic.html#IsClosed.mem_of_tendsto)), and I believe you can make your proof a bit shorter by using it directly.

This can be condensed to
```suggestion
    use a, aU
```

This can be condensed into
```suggestion
    exact h {y} isCompact_singleton
```
Could you prove this using the lemma above?
Note that this change is actually useless. There's nothing wrong with cleaning up the goal of course, but in cases like that we tend to just omit it. Same below.

Here you can just do
```suggestion
    exact this.comp (isProperMap_smul_pair G X)
```

This is how I noticed it: 
- I checked what `assumption` was doing, and noticed it was just the last `have`.
- Unless there's some really weird typing inference going on, doing 
```lean
have : A := by some_tactics
exact this
```
is the same as just doing
```lean
change A
some_tactics
```
- Then I noticed that none of the `change`s were actually necessary.

This is a very small nitpick: instead of `by infer_instance`, you can directly use the term-mode equivalent to the tactic `infer_instance`, which is `inferInstance`.
```suggestion
    refine ⟨inferInstance, fun 𝒰 x₁ x₂ h' ↦ ?_⟩
```

```suggestion
    let ⟨(g, x), hgx1, hgx2⟩ := h.2 h'
```

In general it's not a good idea to use `have` when there is data involved (here, the `g` and the `x`) because `have` forgets any definition of the objects it puts into context. Here this doesn't cause any trouble because there's no definition for `g` and `x`, instead you will just use `hgx1` and `hgx2`. But you'll do yourself a favor by sticking to the "no `have` for data" rule.
Also, it's maybe a bit more idiomatic to use `rcases` here, but `let` is perfectly fine.
I used rcases instead of have but I noticed that it did not match `(g, x)`, I had to use `gx : G × X`. It did not impact the proof though.
For some reason the linter doesn't complain about non-terminal `simp` in hypotheses, but these are also forbidden, please use `simp only`.

Let me introduce you to [Filter.Tendsto.mono_left](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Filter/Basic.html#Filter.Tendsto.mono_left), which should pretty much take care of all of this. `Filter.Tendsto` is used a *lot* so if you have to unfold it there's *probably* a lemma doing what you're trying to do!

```suggestion
    rw [nhds_prod_eq, 𝒰.le_prod]
    exact ⟨hg2, (continuous_snd.tendsto _).comp hxx⟩
```

Notice that the `change` is necessary for the `apply Filter.Tendsto.comp` to work, because Lean essentially has to guess how you want to write your function as a composition. But if you do everything at once, then Lean can just check the type of your term and then check that it is equal to what was expected.

Alternatively, you can also do:
```suggestion
    simp_rw [nhds_prod_eq, Filter.le_prod, Filter.tendsto_prod_iff'] at hxx ⊢
    exact ⟨hg2, hxx.2⟩
```
The reason I use `simp_rw` instead of `rw` is that `rw` expects that each lemma is applicable to *all* places that you're rewriting, while `simp_rw` only wants that each lemma is applicable to *at least* one place.

I'll let you look and play with this suggestion rather than try to explain it, this is the perfect example for learning about our tactic `congrm`.
```suggestion
  rw [properSMul_iff_continuousSMul_ultrafilter_tendsto]
  refine and_congr_right fun hc ↦ ?_
  congrm ∀ 𝒰 x₁ x₂ hxx, ∃ g, ?_
  exact and_iff_right_of_imp fun hg ↦ tendsto_nhds_unique
    (hg.smul ((continuous_snd.tendsto _).comp hxx)) ((continuous_fst.tendsto _).comp hxx)
```
This is quite an amazing shortcut!
Yes, congrm is magic !

Could you move this at the top of the file (right after the module docstring) and also open `Set`? Then you can remove basically all `Filter.` and `Set.` in the rest of the file (some may still be needed for disambiguation).
Just a reminder to come back to these :)

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion {s : Set X} : IsClosed s ↔ ∀ ⦃K⦄, IsCompact K → IsClosed (s ∩ K) := by ```

I see you've replaced a lot of `refine` by `refine'`, but I'm pretty sure we would like instead to get rid of `refine'`, which is a leftover from the port. The syntax of `refine` may look a bit ugly because of all the `?_`, but these actually have a nice semantic distinction: `_` means "Lean should find this alone" while `?_` means "I will prove this later". 

Additionally, note that you can use `?name` instead to create a named goal, which allows you to prove the goals in the order you want, but arguably this is a bit of a gadget.

In fact I hesitated between the two because I thought `?_` avoided confusion with placeholders which were to be found by Lean but on the other hand felt a bit weird. But if we want to get rid of `refine'` then I replace it.
Can you sort the imports alphabetically?

```suggestion
  if the map `(g, x) ↦ (g • x, x)` is proper, in the sense of `IsProperMap`.
```

Could you open a separate PR for changes to this file? Then please add
`- [ ] depends on: #newprnumber`
below the `---` in the description of this PR.
Ah you missed a space, so the bot didn't pick it. I've fixed it now
Thanks

```suggestion
-- See note [lower instance priority]
instance (priority := 100) continuousSmul_of_properSMul [ProperSMul G X] : ContinuousSMul G X where
```
since it always applies (grep to find the note and read it)

This is really hard to read. Please consider reindenting
```suggestion
theorem properSMul_iff_continuousSMul_ultrafilter_tendsto :
    ProperSMul G X ↔ ContinuousSMul G X ∧
      (∀ 𝒰 : Ultrafilter (G × X), ∀ x₁ x₂ : X,
        Tendsto (fun gx ↦ ⟨gx.1 • gx.2, gx.2⟩ : G × X → X × X) 𝒰 (𝓝 (x₁, x₂)) →
      ∃ g : G, g • x₂ = x₁ ∧ Tendsto Prod.fst (𝒰 : Filter (G × X)) (𝓝 g)) := by
```

If you are going to use `refine` right after `constructor`, might as well not use `constructor`.
```suggestion
  refine ⟨fun h ↦ ⟨inferInstance, fun 𝒰 x₁ x₂ h' ↦ ?_⟩, ?_⟩
  · rw [properSMul_iff, isProperMap_iff_ultrafilter] at h
```
Same here regarding indentation

Since you're making `ProperSMul` a typeclass, you should use it as a typeclass argument
```suggestion
theorem t2Space_of_ProperSMul [ProperSMul G X] :
```

Names become `lowerCamelCase` when in a lemma name (or generally in anything whose type is not `Prop` or `Type _`)
```suggestion
theorem t2Space_of_properSMul (hproper:ProperSMul G X) :
```

This name does not mention either of the following very important ingredients that go into the statement:
* `Quotient`
* `MulAction`
* `OrbitRel`

Can you make it less ambiguous?
Nice use of dot notation!
Can this be an `instance`?

If I make it an instance I get a "cannot find synthesization order for instance" error. From what I read this is due to the fact that `G` is not mentioned in the instance. Is there a way to get around this?
No, indeed. You should leave a lemma then.

Again, `UpperCamelCase` becomes `lowerCamelCase` in lemma names, not `snake_case`.
```suggestion
theorem properSMul_of_closedEmbedding {H : Type*} [Group H] [MulAction H X] [TopologicalSpace H]
```
Case issue
Case issue
Case issue

```suggestion

This result should be the only one needed, but the notion of compactly generated space
```
to follow the "short docstring, long docstring convention"
Needed for what? What other result is needed on top? It's not clear from context.

In Lean 4, you get access to nice destruction notation
```suggestion
  isProperMap_vadd_pair' : IsProperMap fun (g, x) : G × X ↦ ⟨g +ᵥ x, x⟩
```

I agree this is prettier, but Anatole had advised me against it because it spawns a match in the infoview. Thus I have to `simp_rw` instead of `rw` in some places. Also it quickly takes a lot of space in the infoview. What do you think?

Maybe this is one case where we should bother the Lean 4 developers for them to make the pretty option easier to use...

If it really is causing you trouble downstream, don't do it.

I conjecture that
```suggestion
@[to_additive existing (attr := mk_iff)]
```
will save you from the `attribute [to_additive existing] properSMul_iff` line (but you should check! I'm not sure)
Didn't work, I get: `(kernel) constant has already been declared 'properVAdd_iff'`.
What if you remove the `@[mk_iff]` in front of `ProperVAdd`?

It doesn't work either. This time I get the following:
```
application type mismatch
  @properSMul_iff G X inst✝¹ inst✝ inst✝³
argument has type
  AddGroup G
but function has type
  ∀ [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : MulAction G X], ProperSMul G X ↔ IsProperMap fun gx ↦ (gx.1 • gx.2, gx.2)
```
in the proofs where I use `properSMul_iff` and there is a `to_additive` attribute.
Okay what about you also add `attribute [to_additive existing] properSMul_iff` after the definition of `ProperSMul` and before you use `properSMul_iff`?
Ok it seems to work, so in the end I removed `@[mk_iff]` in front of `ProperVAdd` instead of removing `attribute [to_additive existing] properSMul_iff`.
Is there a reason why this field is primed? We only prime fields when their type contains some internal construct that we don't want the user to see, which doesn't seem to be the case here
I didn't write the definition and I have no idea why there is a prime. I'll remove it.

```suggestion
instance (priority := 100) ProperSMul.toContinuousSMul [ProperSMul G X] :
    ContinuousSMul G X where
```
Why do we have to name the instance? For the namespace?
For clarity and ease of search
This doesn't seem to exist?
I forgot to change the name in the doc.

```suggestion
      change ∃ g : G, g • y = x
```

```suggestion
      change (MulAction.orbitRel G X).Rel x y -- ↔ (x, y) ∈ gr
```

```suggestion
      change π x = π y  -- ↔ (x, y) ∈ gr
```
etc
Can you update the wording to reflect the new status of compactly generated spaces. Note: you do *not* need to try and add the relevant results.

Here *and throughout*, this reference is capitalized incorrectly.
```suggestion
the map `G × X → X × X` is a proper map (see `IsProperMap`). -/
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: proper group actions

nodes.body: @ADedecker I've created #11769 to see what happens removing the `simp` attribute that caused the linter failure. It seems tricky to really solve the problem.

Here's a first wave of comments. These are mostly about style and shortening some proofs. If you have questions about any of them, please ask, the goal is also that you learn some tricks. Also, if you feel that any suggestion is making the code significantly less readable, feel free to object!
(I'm assigning you, Anatole, since you definitely know the relevant mathematics, but if you think you have participated in this PR to much to review it, feel free to assign eg Floris instead)
